Location: Creag Dubh- Sgurr nan Fhir Duibe
Comments: Isothermic snowpack, new/old snow interface well bonded

Despite warm air temperatures shaded aspects remain firm underfoot. Recent debris observed from a cornice triggered full depth avalanche on an Easterly aspect on Beinn Damph, probably during night of 4th to 5th April.

Location: East ridge, Creag Dhubh, Beinn Eighe.
Comments: Stable isothermal snowpack at profile site.
Poor visibility above 400 metres. Rapidly rising freezing level as day progressed.
Profile not to ground. Deep drifts in sheltered locations on SE aspects. Large accumulations of poorly bonded graupel evident in many places.
Rain has penetrated the surface layer at 750 metre stabilising the snowpack at this height but at higher elevations windslab continues to accumulate.
Recent debris from 2 slab avalanches observed on E aspect at 900m. Easy shear during field observations on NE aspect at 740m.

A stable snowpack with a considerable surface melt freeze crust. The snowpack remains moist at depth.

Location: twin burns near summit of Sgurr a'Chaorachain
Beinn Alligin, Coire nan Laogh, Tom na Gruagaich
Comments: Isothermal snow pack
Isothermal snow pack
Below a very thin surface crust there is a steep temperature gradient and well developed faceted grains; worth bearing in mind in view of heavy snowfall forecast for Sunday night.
Stable well bonded snow at profile site.
Deep drifts on most aspects. Instabilities observed within the recent storm snow. Wind speed and wind direction very variable and gusty both at site and generally.
Instabilities observed within recent storm snow. Poor visibility limited vision but previously observed ice accumulations remain. Continuing snow and North winds expected.
Graupel in abundance collecting in sheltered locations. Good visibility, less build up of snow on Northerly aspects than anticipated.

Location: Sgurr a' Chaorachain (Bealach na Ba Mast)
Comments: Moist surface, dry below. Failure on isolation at 26cms on facets below a thin crust.
The new snow accumulation is mainly graupel of varying size. Obvious layers of large sized graupel exist in the snowpack.
Easy shears observed within surface layer in several sheltered locations.
Snow surface crust peppered with stones (to tennis ball size) blown from the ridges above during the night when winds exceeded 120 mph.
Mostly Graupel and Hail within new accumulations
easy failures in new soft snow on needles and columns
Clear cold day.
Thunder and Lightning, heavy hail showers
